questions.text: Which of the following proteins connects the lines marked as A and B (indicated by red arrows) in the following image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Titin The above image is the electron microscope view of the muscle. Line A corresponds to the M line, and Line B corresponds to the Z line. The protein that connects the M line with the Z line is titin.

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in optic pathway?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Occipital lobe The image shows homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The likely site of the lesion is occipital lobe. Homonymous hemianopia (HH) involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. HH is characteristically seen in lesions involving the visual pathway posterior to the optic chiasma.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted as given below. The type of breathing abnormality seen here is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cheyne-Stokes breathing The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

questions.text: Identify the marked region in the given spirometry.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Functional residual capacity The marked area in the spirometry shows the total amount of air present in the lung after normal expiration. This is called functional residual capacity.

questions.text: In a patient, the hypothalamic thermostat was reset from point A to point C as shown below. Which of the following happens in stage A compared to stage B?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Shivering In the above scenario, the patient’s hypothalamic thermostat has been reset from point A to a higher temperature (point C). The body responds to this change by using certain measures in stage A such as shivering. In stage B, the hypothalamic temperature setpoint is lower than the normal body temperature. Hence body activates various heat loss mechanisms to match the hypothalamic temperature setpoint. It includes vasodilatation of the skin blood vessel, sweating, and decreased thermogenesis.

questions.text: The maximum expiratory flow-volume (MEFV) curves shown in the figure below were obtained from a healthy man (purple curve) and a 57-year-old man with shortness of breath (green curve). What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Emphysema The green curve in the above image and the case scenario denotes that the diagnosis is likely to be emphysema. Maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV): When a person expires with great force, the expiratory airflow reaches a maximum flow beyond which the flow cannot be increased anymore, even with greatly increased additional force.

questions.text: Which of the points on the following figures represent arterial blood in a severely anemic person?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Figure 1-E, Figure 2- D When a person is anemic, there is decrease in O? content of the blood (Fig 1-E) because of decreased number of RBCs and hence hemoglobin content in the blood. The oxygen saturation (Fig 2-D) of the available hemoglobin In the arterial blood is however normal and, the po? is also not affected by the hemoglobin concentration

questions.text: A marathon runner is running a marathon on a hot, humid day. He has profuse sweating resulting in maximum antidiuresis. Maximum water reabsorption will occur in which of the following segments of the nephron?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) PCT Two-thirds of water reabsorption occurs in the PCT. ADH controls 13-15% (23- 27L) of the water reabsorption in the CD. Even if ADH secretion is maximum, maximum water reabsorption occurs in the PCT.

questions.text: The given image shows normal His Bundle Electrogram. The deflection shown by the arrow indicates
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ventricular depolarization The arrow mark shows V deflection of HBE which Indicates ventricular depolarization. His bundle electrogram (HBE): The record of the electrical activity obtained with the catheter passed through a vein to the right side of the heart and placed close to the tricuspid valve is HBE.

questions.text: Given below is the demonstration of tetanization in the gastrocnemius muscle of a frog. Identify the tetanising frequency.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 30-35 Hz Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know, Tetanizing frequency demonstrated by the muscle is 33Hz. In the above graph, we know, - The speed of the paper is 1000mm/sec. - The y-axis represents millivolts, the x-axis represents time. - The scale on the x-axis is 10mm. - The area under the graph represents the muscle contraction. Contraction period (latent period to maximum force of contraction) includes 3 scales = 30 mm. As paper speed is 1000mm/sec, Contraction period = 30mm = (30/1000) = 30 msec. Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period = 1000/30 = 33Hz

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100Hz tuning fork).
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 25 per second. Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period. It is the frequency at which individual muscle fibres twitch that fuse and cause sustained muscle contraction, where the contraction period is the time taken from latent period to maximum force of contraction. In this case, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means the tracer recorded 100 waves per second for one time tracing its 100 -Hz so its duration is 1/100s or 0.01s now contraction period is 4 tracings so CP duration is 0.04s. So tetanizing frequency is 1/contraction period. Hence answer is 1/0.04s=25 Hz.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cell signaling?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Paracrine The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism. In paracrine signaling, the signaling molecules released by a cell only affect target cells in close proximity to it. An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells. Synaptic signaling is a special case of paracrine signaling (for chemical synapses) between neurons and target cells.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Point B to D is refractory period The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period. The sequence of events occurring during an action potential is shown below

questions.text: The phases of the cardiac action potential are represented by the lettered points on the diagram below. At which point on the action potential is the membrane potential most dependent on calcium permeability?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Point C The depolarization phase of the cardiac action potential is due to opening of voltage gated sodium channels and plateau phase is due to potassium efflux and a calcium influx through slow calcium channels (also k/a slow sodium- calcium channels).

questions.text: Identify the hormone from the picture
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Growth hormone The image depicts the fluctuations of secretion of growth hormone throughout the day. Growth hormone is found at relatively low levels during the day unless specific triggers such as strenuous exercise are present. During sleep, on the other hand, large pulsatile bursts of growth hormone secretion occur.

questions.text: During which interval of the ECG does the aortic valve clos?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Aortic valve closes when the ventricles begin to relax and the intra- ventricular pressure becomes lower than the aortic pressure. Ventricular repolarization, represented by the T wave, is followed by ventricular relaxation.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone acts via this pathway?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Leptin The given image shows the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which is associated with tyrosine kinase receptors. Among the given hormones leptin acts via this pathway.

questions.text: The following graph displays which physiological law of the heart?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Starling Law The diagram displays the Length-Tension relationship for a cardiac muscle explaining the Starling law of the heart. In the body, the initial length of the fibers is determined by the degree of diastolic filling of the heart, and the pressure developed in the ventricle is proportional to the volume of the ventricle at the end of the filling phase (Starling law of the heart).

questions.text: Calculate the ejection fraction from the given left ventricular pressure-volume curve:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 60% The ejection fraction as calculated from the above volume pressure curve is 60%. The ejection fraction is defined as the percentage of the end- diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke. Thus, EF Volume ejected / End diastolic volume x 100 The volume ejected can be obtained, by subtracting the end systolic volume from end diastolic volume. Thus, EF = End diastolic volume (EDV) – End systolic volume (ESV) / End diastolic volume (EDV) x 100 In the above volume pressure curve of left ventricle, EDV = 130 ml ESV = 52 ml Substituting these values in the above equation we get, EF (130-52/130) x 100 = (3/5) x 100 = 0.6 × 100 = 60%

questions.text: A nurse in the pulmonology clinic administered a test using the following instrument. Which of the following parameters cannot be measured?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Residual volume The given image shows spirometry. All of the given parameters can be measured by a spirometer except residual volume. Residual volume is measured by: - N? washout method - Helium-dilution method - Body plethysmography Other parameters which cannot be measured by spirometry are: - Functional residual capacity - Total lung capacity
